title: American_Top_40_1973_August_4th
description:
American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This rebroadcast is one of many I have recorded from internet radio. A few are incomplete but most are not and I hope you enjoy these as much as I do.

In this broadcast:

Casey tells about a 45 RPM single that was selling for $10 a copy in 1973! That recording is in this countdown.

A listener asks, "If Roberta Flack's record 'Killing Me Softly' made Record-Of-The-Year that would mean she had Record-Of-The-Year two years in a row. Has this ever happened before?"

One singer-songwriter in the countdown named himself after a dog, to save his real name for when he made it big. Casey tells who.

There is one song in the countdown that the BBC refused to play, causing that song not to be released in the UK.

Formed in 1965, Pink Floyd is on the chart with their first top 40 hit, "Money."

One singer in the coundown got her big break singing in a club to an audience of nearly naked men.

One song in the countdown was first a hit in 1962. The singer learned he had made a comeback while he was earning a living driving a cab.

One song in the countdown tells of the buring down of the studio the song was about to be recorded in. (I know that doesn't make sense but that's what Casey says.)
